para.paratext: Writings that contain a merger clause show that the parties clearly intended for the doctrine of merger to apply and these will be strictly enforced.[1] Some form of merger clause is frequently used in contracts today, especially in sales of personalty. The clause may state that there are no promises, warranties, conditions, or representations not appearing in the writing, or it may take the form of an “all agreements” provision which states that the writing contains all the agreements of the parties. Many other forms are used.

Curtis v. Pierce, 157 Ga. 717, 122 S.E. 208 (1924); Lively v. Munday, 201 Ga. 409, 40 S.E.2d 62, 173, 173 A.L.R. 1295 (1946); Hardin v. Atlanta Gas Light Co., 71 Ga. App. 63, 30 S.E.2d 121 (1944); Kiser v. Godwin, 90 Ga. App. 825, 84 S.E.2d 474 (1954); Spires v. Relco, Inc., 165 Ga. App. 4, 299 S.E.2d 58 (1983); Great American Builders, Inc. v. Howard, 207 Ga. App. 236, 427 S.E.2d 588 (1993) (merger clause was absolute, and, as such, it barred the enforcement of a prior verbal agreement that in fulfillment of its written contract agreement to convey lakefront lots to the plaintiffs, the defendant contractor would provide the plaintiffs with a permanent easement to the lake).

Parol evidence cannot confer third-party beneficiary status where the contract itself fails to do so and contains a merger clause; the law requires that the contracting parties' intention to benefit the third party must be shown on the face of the contract. CDP Event Services, Inc. v. Atcheson, 289 Ga. App. 183, 656 S.E.2d 537 (2008).
